lcInstruction.p: A step can include an example of how the step is performed and some text about the result of having successfully completed the steps.

li.p: Use <stepxmp> (step example) to show an example of how to perform the step.
Use <stepresult> to describe the result of the step.

lcInstruction.p: A step can contain any number of either of these elements, in any order.
lcInstruction.note: The <stepxmp> element shows an example for the current step; to show an example of the entire task, use the <example> element, which is discussed in the next lesson.

p.xref: Video: Adding a step example in a DITA task

step.cmd: Continue working in the file l_task_start.dita.
After the closing tag of the last <step> element, create a new <step> element, containing a <cmd> element and the text shown here.

stepxmp.pre: ...<step><cmd>When you have definitively identified a duck, make a note in your guide.</cmd> </step>...

step.cmd: After the <cmd> element, add a <stepxmp> element.

stepxmp.pre: ...<step><cmd>When you have definitively identified a duck, make a note in your guide.</cmd> <stepxmp> </stepxmp>Â </step>...

step.info: The <stepxmp> element contains an example that illustrates or clarifies the step.

The <stepxmp> element can contain any of the elements that you can use inside an <li> element. To show examples where line breaks and spaces are important, you can use the <pre> element or the <codeblock> element.

stepsection.p: The <stepresult> element describes the result of the successful completion of the step.
The <stepresult> element must be the last element in a <step> element; no other elements can come after it.
